conversation.content: [very quickly] Oye, llevo 3 semanas aprendiendo francés y básicamente ya soy fluido, you should hear my accent!

¿Ah sí? ¿3 semanas enteras, eh? Eso es, em, todo un logro considerando que la mayoría de la gente tarda años en alcanzar la fluidez. ¿Qué puedes decir exactamente hasta ahora, aparte de pedir un croissant?
Puedo decir "dónde está el baño" de 17 maneras diferentes. That's basically all you need, right?

Bueno, o sea, la ubicación del baño es definitivamente importante, pero hay un poco más para la fluidez que eso. Como, eh, ¿puedes mantener una conversación sobre literalmente cualquier otra cosa? El tiempo, direcciones, decirle a alguien que lleva los cordones desatados?
Pfft, ¿por qué necesitaría decirle a alguien que lleva los cordones desatados? Los franceses probablemente ni siquiera llevan zapatos.
Vale vale.
No, en serio, ¿has visto películas francesas? They're always barefoot on beaches eating baguettes.

Eso... eso no es ni remotamente cierto, and I'm honestly kind of impressed by how wrong that is. Los franceses definitivamente llevan zapatos, probablemente más caros que los que tenemos cualquiera de nosotros, y, eh, las playas están mayormente en el sur.
Lo que sea, me voy a cambiar al español de todos modos. It's just English with an 'o' at the end of everything, right? ¿El bathroom-o?

Dios mío, dime que estás de broma. El español tiene estructuras gramaticales completamente diferentes, sustantivos con género, 14 tiempos verbales diferentes, y, em, añadir 'o' a palabras inglesas es básicamente el equivalente lingüístico de llevar un sombrero a Taco Bell.
[relieved] Vale vale, maybe I'll try German. Lo único que haces es gritar todo con rabia, ¿no?

[laugh hard] El alemán no suena inherentemente enfadado, that's just, like, a weird stereotype from war movies! En realidad es bastante melódico cuando se habla correctamente, y honestamente, tiene algunas de las palabras compuestas más lógicamente construidas de cualquier idioma.
¿Lógicamente construidas? ¿Como qué, sauerkraut? Eso significa repollo enfadado.

Literalmente significa repollo agrio, no repollo enfadado, pero buen intento. Y, eh, las palabras compuestas alemanas son realmente fascinantes - tienen palabras como 'verschlimmbessern', which means to make something worse by trying to improve it, que es más o menos lo que estás haciendo con el aprendizaje de idiomas ahora mismo.
Vale, pero esa palabra es increíble. English needs that word immediately.

¿Verdad? Mira, esto es lo que pasa con el aprendizaje de idiomas - cada idioma tiene estos, mmm, conceptos únicos que no se traducen directamente. El japonés tiene 'tsundoku' para comprar libros y nunca leerlos, el portugués tiene 'saudade' para una nostalgia profunda, and, well, English just steals everyone else's words anyway.
[sarcastic] Ah claro, porque el inglés es el único idioma que toma prestadas palabras. El francés nunca cogió nada de nadie.

En realidad el francés es increíblemente protector con la pureza de su idioma, they have an entire academy dedicated to keeping English words out! Inventaron 'courriel' en vez de usar email, y, em, llaman a los hashtags 'mot-dièse', que literalmente significa 'palabra sostenida', y eso me parece extrañamente poético.
[very quietly] Espera, ¿tienen toda una academia solo para odiar las palabras inglesas?

La Académie Française, sí, 40 miembros llamados 'inmortales' que básicamente deciden qué cuenta como francés correcto. Se reúnen todos los jueves llevando estas túnicas verdes elaboradas con bordados dorados, and, honestly, they spend most of their time arguing about whether 'le wifi' should be masculine or feminine.

original_conversation.content: [very quickly] Hey so I've been learning French for three weeks and I'm basically fluent now, you should hear my accent!
Oh really? Three whole weeks, huh? That's, um, that's quite an accomplishment considering most people take years to reach fluency. What exactly can you say so far, besides ordering a croissant?
I can say "where is the bathroom" in seventeen different ways. That's basically all you need, right?

Well, I mean, bathroom location is definitely important, but there's a bit more to fluency than that. Like, uh, can you hold a conversation about literally anything else? Weather, directions, telling someone their shoes are untied?
Pfft, why would I need to tell someone their shoes are untied? French people probably don't even wear shoes.
Okay okay.
No seriously, have you seen French movies? They're always barefoot on beaches eating baguettes.

That's... that's not even remotely accurate, and I'm honestly kind of impressed by how wrong that is. French people definitely wear shoes, probably more expensive ones than either of us own, and, uh, beaches are mostly in the south.
Whatever, I'm switching to Spanish anyway. It's just English with an 'o' at the end of everything, right? El bathroom-o?

Oh god, please tell me you're joking. Spanish has completely different grammar structures, gendered nouns, fourteen different verb tenses, and, um, adding 'o' to English words is basically the linguistic equivalent of wearing a sombrero to Taco Bell.
[relieved] Fine fine, maybe I'll try German. All you do is yell everything angrily, right?

[laugh hard] German isn't inherently angry sounding, that's just, like, a weird stereotype from war movies! It's actually quite melodic when spoken properly, and honestly, it has some of the most logically constructed compound words in any language.
Logically constructed? Like what, sauerkraut? That just means angry cabbage.

It literally means sour cabbage, not angry cabbage, but nice try. And, uh, German compound words are actually fascinating - they have words like 'verschlimmbessern' which means to make something worse by trying to improve it, which is sort of what you're doing to language learning right now.
Okay that word is amazing though. English needs that word immediately.

Right? See, this is the thing about language learning - every language has these, mmm, unique concepts that don't translate directly. Japanese has 'tsundoku' for buying books and never reading them, Portuguese has 'saudade' for a deep nostalgic longing, and, well, English just steals everyone else's words anyway.
[sarcastic] Oh sure, because English is the only language that borrows words. French never took anything from anyone.

Actually French is incredibly protective of their language purity, they have an entire academy dedicated to keeping English words out! They invented 'courriel' instead of using email, and, erm, they call hashtags 'mot-dièse' which literally means 'sharp word' and I find that oddly poetic.
[very quietly] Wait, they have a whole academy just to hate on English words?

The Académie Française, yeah, forty members called 'immortals' who basically decide what counts as proper French. They meet every Thursday wearing these elaborate green robes with gold embroidery, and, honestly, they spend most of their time arguing about whether 'le wifi' should be masculine or feminine.
